Tower of Time est un jeu de rôle aux graphismes agréables, même si on peut regretter une certaine raideur dans l'animation. La direction artistique reste un point fort du titre cependant.

En effet, tout comme dans la plupart des RPG dits "old school", on avance dans l'aventure en constituant un groupe de composition variable, du tank à l'archer en passant par l'artificier. Rien d'original là dedans donc. 

Chaque personnage est paramètrable, de ses skills à la répartation de ses points d'aptitudes. Il est possible par ailleurs d'effectuer des respecialisations à loisir, ce qui permet d'experimenter les tactiques. Un très bon point donc, mais qui nuit à la rejouabilité. Celà dit, c'est dans cet aspect que réside la véritable personnalisation : on est maitre de sa façon de combattre. 

Le système de combat est original dans la mesure où l'on peut passer en mode "ralenti" afin de donner des ordres à notre bande. Au début, c'est quasiment inutile. Un titre plutôt pas mal, pas révolutionnaire, mais qu'on peut espérer voir progresser avant la publication finale. A noter que le rapport qualité/prix est très intéressant.

Tower of Time is a beautiful, story-driven fantasy RPG.  I highly recommend this game.

The most compelling aspect of the game for me is the cutscene artwork.  The still images are breathtaking.  They somehow manage to simultaneously show you how beautiful and developed Altara once was and the dire situation of the world today. The images manage to evoke strong emotions – a feat that few games have accomplished.

Each level is beautifully designed.  Heavy particle areas, such as waterfalls or long-distance renders, will tax your GPU.  It is easy to be immersed in each level and forget that everything you see is within a magic tower.

The story line is top notch and genuinely creative.  You, of course, are the main character, however, as the main character, you sit on your throne and do nothing.  Everything is accomplished by your heroes.  I won’t spoil the novelty of how this is done (from the context of the story).  The story quickly brings together the five races (humans, dwarves, elves, ice giants, and shadows) to give you plenty of options for creating your ideal party.

Each hero has a unique set of skills to give you an edge in combat.  You can easily customize the skills before each battle for a nominal fee.

The approach to combat is certainly unique.  The "slow time" gives you minute control over every detail.  In the early stages, I found this wasn't needed.  As the enemies became stronger with more abilities and combat lasted longer, events happen so quickly that my heroes would die before I realized what was happening.  Trying to micro-manage each hero without the slow-time would be near impossible due to the fast-paced nature of combat.

I would argue that gold is the most precious resource as it is the only resource that cannot be farmed.  You have the option of working through the main story or completing challenges.  Each challenge can be repeated, but you only get the gold and crystal reward once.  The item, however, can be farmed and deconstructed for crystals.  Need to make some new rare armor, but short on crystals?  No problem.  Do a couple challenges and you’re set.  The economy in general will need improvement.

Being an early access game, it has its own set of growing pains.  Improvements that are surely on the developer’s to-do list: no mini-map, can’t remap key assignments, moving around the city can be a little awkward, can’t make notes on the main map (can’t make notes of any kind, for that matter…not that the game is complex enough to require notes, but would be nice to know where certain things are that you think might be important), and can’t adjust the camera – to name a few.

Even with the growing pains, I’m truly excited for the release of the full game and see the storyline thru to its end.  If you are looking for a story to lose yourself in, this is a game you don’t want to miss!

游戏的剧情表面上是一个普通的奇幻故事，但其实故事背景可以看出是精心设计过的，Lore 比较丰富。剧情在初期好像没什么吸引力，并且教学和说明流程有点过多了。头几个小时的内容[strike]除去战斗外[/strike]，比较无聊。好在游戏的剧情属于慢热型，随着流程的推进世界观逐渐饱满，剧情也愈发地引人入胜，让人好奇后续的发展。不过个人认为故事或者流程还是需要在压缩改进一下的。根据开发者的介绍，EA 阶段的游戏内容大致是完整游戏的 30% ~ 40%，从长度上来说也算是诚意十足。游戏的流程虽说是限制在一座高塔之中，场景还是比较丰富的，每深入高塔的一层，地形和场景内容都更加地复杂。

Tower of Time 的核心内容基本就是几乎完全割裂的战斗部分和探索模式了。战斗时游戏会读条进入独立的战斗场景，敌人会像 TD 那样从生成点一波一波地出现。游戏把传统小队战斗 RPG 中的暂停换成了减速，意味其实有点不明的，因为几乎没有什么区别啊！玩家最多可以控制 4 个角色，分别配置 4 个技能进行战斗，目前每个角色最多能学的技能只有 6 个。这种程度的复杂度，暂停换成减速实在没达到什么 让战斗更加刺激的效果。要么，玩家自行选择不用减速功能，把每一次 encounter 纯当作一个小规模 RTS 游戏来完成战斗，说不定能感受到 MOBA 游戏里一控四的快感（？）。

此外，战斗对游戏只是起到了一个推进探索进程的作用，一场战斗下来（中后期的战斗是十分冗长的，敌人的波数会越来越多），仅仅获得些许金币和一两件装备、材料（探索中能搜集到的资源比战斗要多很多）。战斗并不会获得经验，游戏将传统 RPG 的成长系统换成了通过收集金币和图纸升级城市据点的建筑来提高人物等级上限，再..........使用金币来训练角色升级的方式。我真的没有感受到，这个设计相比简单粗暴的打经验升级，带来了什么更有趣的东西。反而是战斗胜利的成就感下降了。并且当我收集够金币后，还要回到据点去一一点击训练来升级人物，这过程明明更繁琐了啊。

探索部分，游戏商店页面介绍中的 challenging puzzles 是一个都没遇到。在下到塔第二层的时候算是遇到了一个小谜题，但也仅仅是一个简单又有点牵强的 riddle 罢了。你总不能跟我说，跑到地图一头捡个东西再跑到另一头触发机关/剧情就算是一个 challenging puzzle 了啊。另外，游戏玩了十几个小时，我也始终不知道介绍中的 Your choices truly matter here. 指的是什么..仔细想了想，大概是指升级的时候点的属性点吧，毕竟游戏不能重置属性点，而且还有把单属性点到 40 以上的成就（？？？）（下次更新好像就可以洗点了...）。探索过程要说比较有趣的，也就是收集和解锁的文献、笔记、播片带来的游戏故事 / lore ，这也是后期我将难度从 hard 调回 story 后继续游戏的仅有动力之一了..。（ EA 阶段未出现的第七个同伴也挺吸引我的，也许会是个特殊角色吧）

还想说的一点就是，玩家在游戏中扮演的主角，并不参与在塔中的探索和战斗.......。而是坐在塔顶的冰封王座（？）上使用剧情赋予的特殊能力，观察甚至操纵着小队伙伴进行活动。除了剧情之外，我不知道这设定是为了营造一种 meta 般的代入感还是什么目的....作为一个 RPG 的主角，只能看着队友们探索战斗对话，偶尔插入一两句台词，反正我是觉得很无趣的...。

作为一款 Early Access 早期的游戏，让人很欣慰的一点是在我十几个小时的游戏时间里，没有遇到过 bug ，已经开放的内容体验比较完整。开发者在社区也很活跃。

对于我来说，游戏给我带来最大的感受就是 真的不够有趣...。希望在后续的更新里能把战斗做的更加有意思一点，让 Tower of Time 真正能像介绍描述的那样，给 classic RPG 带来一些新鲜的东西。 如果对这类题材 / 故事比较感兴趣，这款游戏或许还是值得一试的。

Disclosure：感谢[url=https://cowlevel.net]奶牛关[/url]的野蔷薇项目和开发者提供的评论用 key。本文写于 early access 0.2.0.8117 因此本文不适用于后续更新和完整版。

Tower of Time 是很有野心的作品，希望打破并重新创造 RPG 中已成桎梏的探索 - 战斗 - 成长三环节。然而限于水平、资源以及时间，没有很好地实现他们的理想。话虽如此，我还是支持他们的做法，也能体会到他们的爱和投入。

探索环节基本上就是跑地图，鼠标指哪人走哪，点啥和啥互动，虽然互动 90% 以上基本都是“开这个宝箱”和“拿柜子里的几块钱”。除了个别剧情安排的战斗，每场战之前都能看见这场会出现的敌军配置和具体属性，并可选是开战还是姑且战术撤退韬光养晦，比较透明。一些行为导致的短过场中摄像机运动梆硬，可互动物体很不显眼玩得像找 hidden object 都还好，主要比较不喜欢的是地图设计都非常 video-gamey，看到这个关着的门了吗？看到隔壁的一个把手了吗？你猜这把手是干啥的？还有散落在整个游戏中的尺寸外形一样的宝箱更是别说——这些东西就让我想起玩美末的时候，第一次走到一片空地，上面整整齐齐放着几个半人高的立方体，当时笑得我下巴都要掉了。Tower of Time 好歹也是个精神 cRPG，世界塑造说服力不行。

战斗的部分则发生在与主地图分割的竞技场中，战斗发生前战斗相关数据如 HP，mana，冷却都是不存在的，因此战斗发生时所有角色都是满状态。每个角色同时至多拥有四个技能，分别绑在Q、W、E 和 R 键上，倒是很方便操作没错了……商店页面描述的“你可以随心所欲让时间减速”根本就是一个和所有无限引擎 RPG 一样的暂停然后发布命令功能，只是本作中不是暂停而是时间以极慢的速度流动，和暂停没有本质区别。除了个别 boss 战，所有战斗都是敌人分波刷新的生存战（早期过后波数和敌人的数量就多得累人了），加上敌兵多样性的极其匮乏，一些战斗可以说是非常的 grind，时常你会连续碰到许多场完全一模一样的战斗，发生在一模一样的竞技场。偶尔你会碰到一场让你挑战极限的战斗，这种时刻让人能体验到玩这个游戏的意义，其余时刻战斗都太简单或者太难，主要还是太久。而且出于一些原因 Event Horizon 决定让敌兵以远程为主，结合竞技场地图的尺寸大得没啥必要，战斗中许多时间你的近战角色都在刷新点之间疲于奔命。

而成长部分则发生在外头的据点中，两个词能够基本表达我想说的意思：Darkest Dungeon。基本上你用探索和战斗中收集的资源来提升据点中建筑的等级，并以此提升角色等级、能力与装备。但我很怀疑开发者是先想着要做个据点管理决定角色成长再去设计游戏内容的，因为可升级建筑的种类实在太过匮乏。除了铁匠铺，所有其他可升级建筑都是角色等级建筑，因此据点基本可以说是只存在建设，不存在管理。加上资源除了现金只有锻造材料，资源管理也可以说是完全没有。每个角色有六个技能并选择四个使用，随时可以洗点，可以说是提供了一定的灵活性，但许多技能完全雷同只是换个模型和元素属性让我没法说技能多种多样这样的话。

以上就是核心玩法方面。总体来说差强人意，虽然点子是正没错，但执行能力实在是缺了太多。

除了这些，游戏的故事倒是感觉挺吸引人的，目前来看没有完成，但还算比较期待看到最后是怎样。flavor text 的数量也是相当大。画面称不上好看，但也有不错的时刻。音乐还可以，但只有那么几首曲目玩了 14 个小时下来也是挺得耳朵长茧。比较难受的是 UI 设计真的比较次，但我相信这是随着游戏开发进度最容易改善的部分。

总体来说这不是一个让我玩得很舒服的游戏。但出于对他们一个波兰小厂想改变 RPG 公式的野心和游戏中可以感受到的他们制作的热情，我还是真心支持。希望他们能越走越远，也希望 Tower of Time 能随着开发变得更好玩。

Tower of Time is an exquisitely beautiful RPG with an intriguing storyline. 

The game world is individually crafted, down to the smallest detail.  Many of the puzzles in the game involved noticing tiny details and clicking on them. There are also hidden rooms that are behind thick vegetations and journal updates that are hidden in libraries.  The landscapes are also very beautiful, including ice-covered caves, mechanical gadgets and a mix of technology and magic. 

The game mechanics might be a bit difficult for those people that are used to turn-based RPG games. In fact, the games happen in real time, but you are given the opportunity to slow down time. However, even so, the fighting will keep you busy and you need to micro-manage them if you are playing on hard or epic levels. There is also the option of playing the game in easy or "story" levels as well. The player is given the choice of playing the game at any levels that he is most comfortable with.

The game world is extremely huge and consists of dungeons of many levels. Each level is made up of multiple sectors and the map is interspersed with teleportals to enable easy travel. Currently the game is in Early Access and more than half the contents are still under development. However, the contents that are currently release has given me many days of pleasure and enjoyment.

This game is like an exquisite gem and I would highly recommend it.

[h1]INTRODUCTION[/h1]
One of the things we love most about Steam is that is provides a mechanism for small developers and publishers to get their games in front of players who are interested, and although there are plenty of indie disappointments, you can find some gems if you look. I recently bumped into an indie title called Tower of Time, developed and published by a small developer in Poland called Event Horizon, and had quite a bit of fun with it.

Event Horizon launched Tower of Time as an Early Access title on July 13. The game is a single-player, isometric top-down dungeon crawler with RTS elements that takes place inside a huge, multi-level tower that was unearthed during an earthquake in a dying world. 

[h1]STORY[/h1]

Your character was drawn to the tower as a child, and you briefly entered the structure and talked to a presence that said you’d return someday to claim the power waiting there for you. Many years later, you indeed re-enter the tower in search of resources to help the citizens of your city, where continuous failed crops and the scarcity of clean water have threatened your people’s future.

You initially return with two trusted friends and warriors, a prototypical male fighter and a female archer. They encourage you to let them go ahead and scout the tower and make it safe for you, which works out as you have a date with a large crystal throne you first glimpsed as a child. From that point on, you direct your companions’ actions via the power of the throne, and as the game progresses you are introduced to new characters to add to your party of up to four.

[H1]GAMEPLAY[/H1]

Your team will explore the tower, fight monsters, and gain valuable insight as to what your world was like before its decline, as well as what caused it to begin dying in the first place. Most battles you can choose to initiate or postpone, as you can see many of the monsters in the tower milling about and waiting to kill you. Some battles, though, are unavoidable: sometimes your party is ambushed, and other times you have to engage an enemy force to progress further into the tower and solve its mysteries.

Once you enter combat, the game switches perspectives to give you a broader view of the battlefield, and you are allowed to position your adventurers wherever you like prior to starting the fight. This is advantageous for getting your ranged fighters and casters where they can be most effective, although you’ll need to move all your characters around quite a bit during some fights. Once you start each battle, enemies will spawn from multiple locations on the map and attack, and you’ll control your team members’ movement and abilities in real-time while managing their health, mana, and ability cooldowns. The game’s combat isn’t unlike the Tactical View in EA and Bioware’s Dragon Age games, and although you can’t freeze the fight completely, there is a Slow Time button that you can use as much as you like when things get hairy. And things will get hairy; the first few fights might suggest otherwise, but once you have a full party and have to manage ranged DPS, melee, and healing/buffs in real time, you’ll be glad you can slow things down occasionally.

[H1]CONCLUSION[/H1]

There are plenty of time-worn fantasy tropes on display in Tower of Time, and I ran across a minor glitch or two, as well, but given its Early Access status and its very budget-friendly price of $15(also, 15% off until January 15), I think there’s more than enough fun in this game to outweigh such concerns.
